conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the Ampere force received by the wire ABC, we need to consider the forces acting on each segment of the wire separately due to the magnetic field.
Segment AB is in a magnetic field pointing inward (out of the page).

premise: Segment AB is in a magnetic field pointing inward (out of the page).
conclusion: The force on segment AB, \( \vec{F_{AB}} \), is given by \( \vec{F_{AB}} = I \cdot \vec{L_{AB}} \times \vec{B} \).

premise: The force on segment AB, \( \vec{F_{AB}} \), is given by \( \vec{F_{AB}} = I \cdot \vec{L_{AB}} \times \vec{B} \).
conclusion: Since \( \vec{B} \) points out of the page and \( \vec{L_{AB}} \) points from A to B, the cross product \( \vec{L_{AB}} \times \vec{B} \) results in a force in the downward direction.

premise: Since \( \vec{B} \) points out of the page and \( \vec{L_{AB}} \) points from A to B, the cross product \( \vec{L_{AB}} \times \vec{B} \) results in a force in the downward direction.
conclusion: The magnitude of the force on AB is \( F_{AB} = IBL \).
Segment BC is in a magnetic field pointing outward (into the page).

premise: Segment BC is in a magnetic field pointing outward (into the page).
conclusion: The force on segment BC, \( \vec{F_{BC}} \), is given by \( \vec{F_{BC}} = I \cdot \vec{L_{BC}} \times \vec{B} \).

premise: The force on segment BC, \( \vec{F_{BC}} \), is given by \( \vec{F_{BC}} = I \cdot \vec{L_{BC}} \times \vec{B} \).
conclusion: Since \( \vec{B} \) points into the page and \( \vec{L_{BC}} \) points from B to C, the cross product \( \vec{L_{BC}} \times \vec{B} \) also results in a force in the downward direction.

premise: Since \( \vec{B} \) points into the page and \( \vec{L_{BC}} \) points from B to C, the cross product \( \vec{L_{BC}} \times \vec{B} \) also results in a force in the downward direction.
conclusion: The magnitude of the force on BC is \( F_{BC} = IBL \).

premise: The magnitude of the force on AB is \( F_{AB} = IBL \). The magnitude of the force on BC is \( F_{BC} = IBL \).
conclusion: Since both forces \( \vec{F_{AB}} \) and \( \vec{F_{BC}} \) are in the same direction (downward), the total force \( \vec{F_{total}} \) is the sum of these two forces.
